title: What's it called when an author uses a different name? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not entirely sure if this is the exact term that is often used, but I believe the word you are looking for is a “pseudonym”. For example, J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, uses the abbreviation “J.K.”- a combonation of her first name, Joanne, and the middle name Kathleen- in addition to her last name. This name was formed after her publisher reccomended that she use a male, or at least a less feminine-esque name. She also has another publishing name which she published a series known as The Cucco’s Calling under: “Robert Galbraith”.

The fake name can be called “pen name,” or, with a little bit of flair, a “nom de plume” (which is French for “pen name"), or, in a highbrow setting, a “pseudonym" (which is Greek for “false name"). Works written under an assumed name (it can be called that, too) are called “pseudonymous," as in “Huckleberry Finn is the best of Samuel Clemens' pseudonymous novels.“
